title: economics
content: The study of the choices people make to attain their goals, given their scarce resources.

title: economic model
content: A simplified version of reality used to analyze real-world economic situation.

title: goods
content: Goods are tangible merchandise, such as books, computers, or Blu-ray players.

title: market
content: A group of buyers and sellers of a good or service and the institution or arrangement by which they come together to trade.

title: scarcity
content: A stituation in which unlimited wants exceed the limited resources available to fulfill those wants.

title: marginal analysis
content: Analysis that involves comparing marginal benefits and marginal costs.

title: marginal benefit
content: The additional benefit to a consumer from consuming one more unit of a good or service.

title: opportunity cost
content: The highest valued alternative that mast be given up to engage in an activity.

title: trade-offs
content: The idea that because of scarcity, producing more of one good or service means producing less of another good or service.

title: centrally planned economy
content: An economy in which the government decide how economic resources will be allocated.

title: Market economy
content: An economy in which the decisions of households and firms interacting in markets allocate economic resources.

title: allocative efficiency
content: A state of the economy in which production is in accordance with consumer preferences in particular, every good or service is produced up to the point where the last unit provides a marginal benefit to society equal to the marginal cost of producing it.

title: mixed economy
content: An economy in which most economic decisions result from the interaction of buyers and sellers in markets but in which the government plays a significant role in the allocation of resources.

title: productive efficiency
content: A situation in which a good or service is produced at the lowest possible cost.

title: voluntary exchange
content: A situation that occurs in markets when both the buyers and seller of a product are made better off by the transaction.

title: equity
content: The fair distribution of economic benefits.

title: Economic variable
content: Something measurable that can have different values, such as the income of doctors.

title: normative analysis
content: Analysis concerned with what ought to be.-

title: positive analysis
content: Analysis concerned with what is.

title: macroeconomics
content: The study of the economy as a whole, including topic such as inflation, unemployment, and economic growth.

title: microeconomics
content: The study of how households and firms make choices, how they interact in markets, and how the government attempts to influence their choices.

title: Entrepreneur
content: Someone who operates a business and decides what goods and service to produce and how to produce them. An entrepreneur starting a new business puts his or her own funds atrisk. If an entrepreneur is wrong about what consumers want or about the best way to produce goods and services, the entrepreneur鈥檚 funds can be lost.

title: Innovation
content: The practical application of an invention.

title: Technology
content: The processes a firm uses to produce goods and service.

title: Firm, company, or business
content: A firm is an organization that produces a good or service.

title: Services
content: Services are activities done for others, such as providing haircuts or investment advice.

title: Revenue
content: A firm's revenue is the total amount received for selling a good or service. It is calculated by multiplying the price per unit by the number of units sold.

title: Profit
content: A firm鈥檚 profit is the difference between its revenue and its costs. Economists distinguish between accounting profit and economic profit. In calculating accounting profit, we exclude the cost of some economic resources that the firm does not pay for explicitly. In calculating economic profit, we include the opportunity cost of all resources used by the firm. When we refer to profit in this book, we meaneconomic profit. It is important not to confuse profit with revenue.

title: Household
content: A household consists of all persons occupying a home. Households are suppliers of factors of production鈥攑articularly labor鈥攗sed by firms to make goods and services. Households also demand goods and services produced by firms and governments.

title: Factors of production or economic resources
content: Firms use factors of production to produce goods and services. The main factors of production are labor, capital, natural resources鈥攊ncluding land鈥攁nd entrepreneurial ability. Households earn income by supplying to firms the factors of production.

title: Capital
content: The word capital can refer to financial capital or to physical capital. Financial capital includes stocks and bonds issued by firms, bank accounts, and holdings of money. In economics, though, capital refers to physical capital, which includes manufactured goods that are used to produce other goods and services. Examples of physical capital are computers, factory buildings, machine tools, ware-houses, and trucks. The total amount of physical capital available in a country is referred to as the country鈥檚 capital stock.

title: Human capital
content: Human capital refers to the accumulated training and skills that workers possess. For example, college-educated workers generally have more skills and are more productive than workers who have only high school degrees.

title: total revenue
content: The total amount of funds received by a seller of a good or service, calculated by multiplying price per unit by the number of unit s sold.

title: production possibilities frontier
content: A curve showing the maximum attainable combinations of two products that may be produced with availalbe resources and current technology.

title: Opportunity cost
content: The highest-valued alternative that must be given up to engage in an activity.

title: economic growth
content: The ability of the economy to increase the production of goods and services.

title: trade
content: The act of buying and selling

title: absolute advantage
content: The ability of an individual, a firm, or a country to produce more of a good or service than competitors, using the same amount of resources.

title: comparativve advantage
content: The ability of an individual, a firm, or a country to produce a good or service at a lower opportunity cost than competitors.

title: factor markets
content: A market for the factors of productions, such as labor, capital, natural resources, and entrepreneurial ability.

title: factor of productions
content: The inputs used to make goods and services.

title: product markets
content: A market for goods-such as computers-or services-such as medical treatment.

title: circular-flow diagram
content: A model that illustrates how participants in markets are linked.

title: free markets
content: A market with few government restrictions on how a good or service can be produced or sold or on how a factor of production can be employed.

title: entrepreneur
content: Someone who operates a business, bringing together the factors of production - labors, capital, and natural resources - to produce goods and service.

title: property rights
content: The rights individuals or firms have to the exclusive use of their property, including the right to buy or sell it.

title: demand curve
content: A curve that shows the relationship between the price of a product and the quantity of the product demanded.

title: demand schedule
content: A table that shows the relationship between the price of a product and the quantity of the product demanded.

title: market demand
content: The demand by all the consumers of a given good or service.

title: perfectly competitive market
content: A market the meets the conditions of (1)many buyers and sellers, (2)all firms selling identical products, and (3)no barriers to new firms entering the market.

title: quantity demanded
content: The amount of a good or service that a consumer is willign and able to purchase at a given price.

title: income effect 71
content: The change in the quantity demanded of a good that results from the effect of a change in the good's price on consumers' purchasing power.

title: law of demand
content: The rule that, holding everything else constant, when the price of a product falls, the quantity demanded of the product will increase, and when the price of a product rises, the quantity demanded of the product will decrease.

title: income effect
content: THe change in the quantity demanded of a good that results from the effect of a change in the good's price on consumers' purchasing power.

title: substitution effect
content: The change in the quantity demanded of a good that results a change in price, making the good more or less expensive relative to other goods that are consumers.

title: ceteris paribus
content: The requirement that when analyzing the relationship between two variables - such as price and quantity demanded - other variable must be held constant.

title: inferior good
content: A good for whic the demand increases as income falls and decreases as income rises.

title: normal good
content: A good for which the demand increases as income rises and decreases as income falls.

title: substitues
content: Goods and services that can be used for the same purpose.

title: complements
content: Goods and services that are used together.

title: demographics
content: The characteristics of a population with respect to age, race, and gender.

title: quantity supplied
content: The amount of a good or service that a firm is willing and able to supply at a given price.

title: supply curve
content: A curve that shows the relationship between the price of a product and the quantity of the product supplied.

title: supply schedule
content: A table that shows the relationship between the price of a product and the quantity of the product supplied.

title: law of supply
content: The rule that, hoking everything else constant, increases in price cause increases in the quantity supplied, and decreases in the price cause decreases in the quantity supplied.

title: technological change
content: A positive or negative change in the ability of a firm to produce a given level of output with a given quantity of input.

title: competitive market equilibrium
content: A market equilibrium with many buyers and many sellers.

title: market equilibrium
content: A situation in which quantity demanded equals quantity supplied.

title: shortage
content: A situation in which the quantity demanded is greater than the quantity supplied.

title: surplus
content: A situation in which the quantity supplied is greater than the quantity demanded.

title: Price celling
content: A legally determined maximum price that sellers may charge.

title: Price floor
content: A legally determined minimun price that sellers may receive.

title: consumer surplus
content: The difference between the highest price a consumer is willing to pay for a good or service and the price the consumer actually pays.

title: producer surplus
content: The difference between the lowest price a firm would be willing to accept for a good or service and the price it actually receives.

title: economic efficiency
content: A market outcome in which the marginal benefit to consumers of the last unit produced is equal to its marginal cost of production and in which the sum of consumer surplus and producer surplus is at a maximum.

title: deadweight loss
content: The reduction in economic surplus resulting from a market not being in competitive equilibrium.

title: economic surplus
content: The sum of consumer surplus and producer surplus.

title: black markets
content: A market in which buying and selling take place at prices that violate government price regulations.

title: Externality
content: A benefit or cost that affects someone who is not directly involved in the production or consumption of a good or service.

title: private benefit
content: The benefit received by the consumer of a good or service.

title: private cost
content: The cost borne by the producers of a good or service.

title: social benefit
content: The total benefit from consuming a good or service, including both pricate venefit and any external benefit.

title: social cost
content: The total cost of producing a good or service, including both the private cost and any ecternal cost.

title: market failure
content: A situation in which the market fails to produce the efficient level of output.

title: Property rights
content: The rights individuals or business have to the exclusive use of their property, including the right to buy or sell it.

title: coase theorem
content: The argument of economist Ronald Coase that if transactions costs are low, private bargaining will result in an efficient solution to the problem of externalities.

title: transactions costs
content: The costs in time and other resources that parties incur in the process of agreeing to and carrying out an exchange of goods or services.

title: command-and-control approach
content: An approach that involves the government imposing quantitative limits on the amount of pullution firms are allowed to emit or requiring firms to install specific pollution control devices.

title: Pigovian taxes and subsidies
content: Government taxed and subsidies intended to bring about an efficient level of output in the presence of externalities.

title: common resource
content: A good that is rival but not excludable

title: excludability
content: The situation in which anyone who does not pay for a good cannot consume it.

title: free riding
content: Benefiting from a good without paying for it.

title: private good
content: A good that is both rival and excludable.

title: public good
content: A good that is both nonrival and nonexcludable.

title: rivalry
content: The situation that occurs when one person's consuming a unit of a good means no one else can consume it.

title: tragedy of the commons
content: The tendency for a common resource to be overused.

title: elasticity
content: A measure of how much one economic variable responds to changes in another economic variable.

title: price elasticity of demand
content: The responsiveness of the quantity demanded to a change in price, measured by dividing the percent age change in the quantity demanded of a product by the percentage change in the product's price.

title: elastic demand
content: Demand is elastic when the percentage change in quantity-demanded is greater than the percentage change in price, so the price elasticity is greater than 1 in abosolute value.

title: inelastic demand
content: Demand is inelastic when the percentage change in quantity demanded is less than the percentage change in price, so the price elasticity is less than 1 in absolute value.

title: unit-elastic demand
content: Demand is unit elastic when the percentage change in quantity demanded is equal to the percentage change in price, so the price elasticity is equal to 1 in absolute value.

title: perfectly inelastic demand
content: The case where the quantity demanded is completely unrespnsive to price and the price elasticity of demand equals zero.

title: perfectly elastic demand
content: The case where the quantity demanded is infinitely responsive to price and the price elasticity of demand equals infinity.

title: cross-price elasticity of demand
content: The percentage change in quantity demanded of one good divided by the percnetage change in the price of another good.

title: income elasticity of demand
content: Measure of the responsiveness of quantity demanded to changes in income, measured by the percentage change in quantity demanded divided by the percentage change in income.

title: price elasticity of supply
content: The responsiveness of the quantity supplied to a change in price, measured by dividing the percentage change in the quantity supplied of a product by the percentage change in the product's price.

title: health care
content: The goods and services, such as prescription drugs and consultations with a doctor, that are intended to maintian or improve a person's health.

title: health insurance
content: A contact under which a buyer agrees to make payments, or premiums, in exchane for the provider's agreeing to pay some or all of buyer's medical bills.

title: fee-for-service
content: A system under which doctors and hospitals receive a separate payment for each service that they provide.

title: Single-payer health care system
content: A system, such as the one in Canada, in which the government provides health insurance to all of the country's residents.

title: socialized medicine
content: A health care system under which the government owns most of hospitals and employs most of the doctors.

title: asymmetric information
content: A situation in which one party to an economic transaction has less information than the other party.

title: adverse selection
content: The situation in which one party to a transaction takes advantage of knowing more than the other party to the transaction.

title: moral hazard
content: The actions people take after they have entered into a transaction that make the other party to the transaction worse off.

title: patient protection of addordable care act
content: Health care reform legislation passed by Congress and signed by Persident Barack Obama in 2010.

title: market-based reforms
content: Changes in the market for health care that would make it more like the markets for other goods and services.

title: Sole proprietorship
content: A firm owned by a single individual and not organized as a coporation.

title: Partnership
content: A firm owned jointly by two or more persons and not organized as a coporation.

title: Corporation
content: A legal form of business that provide owners with protection from losing more than their investment should the business fall.

title: asset
content: Anything of value owned by a person of a firm.

title: limited liability
content: The legal provision that shields owners of a corporation from losing more than they have invested in the firm.

title: corporate governance
content: The way in which a corporation is structured and the effect that structure has on the corporation's behavior.

title: pricipal-agent problem
content: A problem caused by agents pursuing their own interests rather than the interests of the principals who hired them.

title: separation of ownership from control
content: A situation in a corporation in which the top management, rather than the shareholders, control day-to-day operations.

title: bonds
content: A financial security that represents a promise to repay a fixed amount of funds.

title: coupoh payments
content: An interest payment on a bond.

title: direct finance
content: A flow of funds from savers to firms through financial markets, such as the New York Stork Exchange.

title: indirect finance
content: A flow of funds from savers to borrowers through financial intermediaries such as banks. Intermediaries raise funds from savers to lend to firms(and other borrowers).

title: interest rates
content: The cost of borrowing funds, usually expressed as a percentage of the amount borrowed.

title: dividends
content: Payments by a corporation to its shareholders.

title: stock
content: A financial security that represents partial ownership of a firm.

title: accounting profit
content: A firm net income, measured as revenue minus operating expenses and taxes paid.

title: explicit cost
content: A cost that involves spending money.

title: implicit costs
content: A nonmonetary opportunity cost.

title: income statement
content: A financial statement that sums up a firm's revenues, costs, and profit over a period of time.

title: liability
content: Anything owed by a person or a firm.

title: balance sheet
content: A financial statement that sums up a firm's financial position on a perticular day, usually the end of a quarter or year.

title: economic profit
content: A firm's revenues minus all of its implict and explict costs.

title: Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act
content: Legislation passed during 2010 that was intended to reform regulation of the financial system.

title: present value
content: The value in today's dollars of funds to be paid or received in the future.

title: stockholders' equity
content: The difference between the value of a corporation's assets and the value of its liabilities; also known as net worth

title: exports
content: Goods and services produced domestically but sold in other countries.

title: imports
content: Goods and services bought domestically but produced in other countries.

title: tariff
content: A tax imposed by a government on imports.

title: autarky
content: A situation in which a country does not trade with other countries.

title: terms of trade
content: The ratio at which a country can trade its exports for imports from other countries.

title: external economies
content: Reduction in a firm's costs that result from an increase in the size of an industry.

title: free trade
content: Trade between countries that is without government restrictions.

title: quota
content: A numerical limit a government imposes on the quantity of a good that can be imported into the country.

title: voluntary export restraint
content: A agreement negotiated between two countries that places a numberical limit on the quanlity of a good that can be imported by one country from the other country.

title: globalization
content: The process of countries becoming more open to foreign trade and investment.

title: World Trade Organization
content: An international organization that oversees international trade agreements.

title: protectionism
content: The use of trade barriers to shield domestic firm from foreign competition.

title: dumping
content: Selling a product for a price below its cost of production.

title: utility
content: The enjoyment or satisfaction people receive from consuming goods and services.

title: budget constraint
content: The limited amount of income available to consumers to spend on goods and services.

title: law of diminishing marginal utility
content: The principle that consumers experience diminshing additional satisfaction as they consume more of a good or service during a given period of time.

title: marginal utility
content: In total utility a person receives from consuming one additional unit of a good or service.

title: Income effect
content: The change in the quantity demanded of a good that results from the effect of a change in price on consumer purchasing power, holding all other factors constant.

title: Subsitution effect
content: The change in the quantity demanded of a good that results from a change in price making the good more or less expensive relative to other goods, holding constant the effect of the prive change on consumer purchasing power.

title: network externality
content: A statement in which the usefulness of a product increases with the number of consumers who use it.

title: behavioral economics
content: The study of situation in which people make choices that do not appear to be economically rational.

title: endowment effect
content: The tendency of people to be unwilling to sell a good they already owen even if they are offered a price that is greater thant the price they would be willing to pay to buy the good if they didn't already own it.

title: sunk cost
content: A cost that has already been paid and cannot be recovered.

title: long run
content: The period of time in which a firm can vary all its inputs, adopt new technology, and increase or decrease the size of its physical plant.

title: short run
content: The period of time during which at least one of a firm's inputs is fixed.

title: indifference curve
content: A curve that shows the combinations of consumption boundles that give the consumer the same utility.

title: marginal rate of substitution
content: The ratio at which a consumer would be willing to trade one good for another.

title: technology
content: The process a firm uses to turn imputs into outputs of goods and services.

title: Technological change
content: A change in the ability of a firm to produce a given level of ouput with a given quantity of inputs.

title: fixed-cost
content: Costs that remain constant as output changes.

title: total cost
content: The cost of all the inputs a firm uses in production.

title: variable costs
content: Costs that change as output changes.

title: production function
content: The relationship between the inputs employed by a firm and the maximum output it can produce with those inputs.

title: Average total cost
content: Total cost divided by the quantity of output produced.

title: average tax rate
content: Total tax paid divided by total income.

title: Marginal product of labor
content: The additional output a firm produces as a result of hiring one more worker.

title: law of diminishing returens
content: The principle that, at some point, adding more of a variable, such as labor, to the same amount of a fixed input, such as capital, will cause the marginal product of the variable input to decline.

title: average product of labor
content: The total output produced by a firm divided by the quantity of workers.

title: marginal cost
content: The change in a firm's total cost from producing one more unit of good or service.

title: average fixed cost
content: Fixed cost divided by the quantity of output produced.

title: average variable cost
content: Variable cost divided by the quantity of output produced.

title: economies of scale
content: The situation when a firm's long run average costs fall as it increases the quantity of output it produces.

title: long-run average cost curve
content: A curve that shows the lowest cost at which a firm is able to produce a given quantity of output in the long run, when no inputs are fixed.

title: constant returns to scale
content: The situation in which a firm's long-run average costs remain unchanged as it increases output.

title: diseconomies of scale
content: The situation in which a firm's long-run average costs rise as the firm increases output.

title: minimum efficient scale
content: The level of output at which all economies of scale are exhausted.

title: isoquant
content: A curve that shows all the combination of two inputs, such as capital and labor, that will produce the same level of output.

title: isocost line
content: All the combination of two inputs, such as capital and labor that have the same total cost.

title: marginal rate of technical substitution
content: The rate of which a firm is able to substitute one input for another while keeping the level of output constant.

title: expansion path
content: A curve that shows a firm's cost minimizing combination of inputs for every level of output.

title: price taker
content: A buyer or seller that is unable to affect the market price.

title: profit
content: Total revenue minus total cost.

title: average revenue
content: Total revenue divided by the quantity of the product sold.

title: marginal ravenue
content: The change in total revenue from selling one more unit of a product.

title: shutdown point
content: The minimum point on a firm's average variable cost curve. If the price fall below this point, the firm shuts down production in the short run.

title: Economic profit
content: A firm's revenue minus all its costs, implict and explicts.

title: economic loss
content: The situation in which a firm's total revenue is less than its total cost, inclusing all implict costs.

title: long-run competitive equilibrium
content: The situation in which the entry and exit of firms has resulted in the typical firm breaking even.

title: long-run supply curve
content: A sucve that shows the relationship in the long run between market price and the quantity supplied.

title: Production efficiency
content: The situation in which a good or service is produced at the lowest possible cost.

title: Allocative efficiency
content: A state of the economy in which production represents consumer preferences in particular, every good or service is produced up to the point where the last unit provides a marginal benefit to consumers equal to the marginal cost of producing it.

title: monopolistic competition
content: A market structure in which barriers to entry are low and many firms compete by selling similar but not identical products.

title: marketing
content: All the activities necessary for a firm to sell a product to a consumer.

title: brand management
content: The actions of a firm intended to maintian the differentiation of a product over time.

title: oligopoly
content: A market structure in which a small number of interdependent firms compete.

title: economies of scale
content: The situation when a firm's long-run average costs fall as the firm increases output.

title: barrier to entry
content: Anything that keeps new firms from entering an industry in which firms are earning economic profits.

title: patents
content: The exclusive right to a product for a period of 20 years from the date the patent is filled with the government.

title: business strategy
content: Action that a firm take to achieve a goal, such as maximizing profits.

title: game theory
content: The study of how people make decision in situation in which attaining their goals depends on their interactions with others in economics, the study of the decisions of firms in industries where the profits of a firm depend on its interactions with other firms.

title: payoff matrix
content: A table that show the payoffs that each firm earns from every combination of stragies by the firms.

title: collusion
content: An agreement among firms to charge the same price or otherwise not to compete.

title: cooperative equilibrium
content: An equilibrium in a game in which players cooperate to increase their mutual payoff.

title: dominant strategy
content: A strategy that is the best for a firm, no matter what strategies other firms use.

title: Nash equilibrium
content: A situation in which each firm chooses the best stragies given the strategies chosen by other firms.

title: noncooperative equilibrium
content: An equilibrium in a game in which players do not cooperate but pursue their owen self-interest.

title: prisoner's dilemma
content: A game in which pursuing dominant strategies results in noncooperation that leaves everyone worse off.

title: price leadership
content: A form of implict collusion in which one firm in an oligopoly announce a price change and the other firms in the industry match the charge.

title: cartel
content: A group of firms that collude by a agreeing to restrict output to increase prices and profits.

title: Monoploy
content: A firm that is the only seller of a good or service that does not have a close substitute.

title: Copyright
content: A government-granted exclusive right to produce and sell a creation.

title: Public franchise
content: A government description that a firm is the only legal provider of a good or service.

title: Natural monopoly
content: A situation in which economies of scale are so large that one firm can supply the entire market at a lower average total cost than can two or more firms.

title: Market power
content: The ability of a firm to charge a price greater than marginal cost.

title: Antitrust law
content: Laws aimed at eliminating collusion and promoting competition among firms.

title: Horizontal merger
content: A merger between firms in the same industry.

title: Vertical merger
content: A merger between firms at different stages of production of a good.

title: transaction cost
content: The cost in time and other resources that parties incur in the process of agreeing to and carrying out an exchange of goods or services.

title: price discrimination
content: Charging different price to different customers for the same product when the price difference are not due to differences in cost.

title: two-part traiff
content: A situation in which consumers pay one price (or tariff) for the right to buy as much of a related good as they want at a second price.

title: derived demand
content: The demand for a factor or production; it depends on the demand for the good the factor produces.

title: marginal revenue product of labor
content: The change in a firm's revenue as a result of hiring one more worker.

title: human capital
content: The accumulated training and skills that workers possess.

title: compensating differentials
content: Higher wage that compensate workers for unpleasant aspects of a job.

title: economic discrimination
content: Paying a person a lower wage or excluding a person from an occupation on the basis of an irrelevant characteristic such as race or gender.

title: labor unions
content: An organization of employees that has a legal right to bargain with employers about wages and working conditions.

title: personnel economics
content: The application of economic analysis to human resources issues.

title: economic rent
content: The price of a factor of production that is in fixed supply.

title: pure rent
content: The price of a factor of production that is in fixed supply.

title: monopsony
content: The sole buyer of a factor of production.

title: marginal pruductivity theory of income distribution
content: The theory that the distribution of income is determined by the marginal productivity of the factors of production that individuals own.

title: public choice model
content: A model that applies economic analysis to government decision making.

title: arrow impossibility theorem
content: A mathematical theorem that holds that no system of voting can be devised that will consistently represent the underlying preference of voters.

title: median voter theorem
content: The proposition that the outcome of a majority vote is likely to represent the preference of the vote who is in the political middle.

title: voting paradox
content: The failure of mojority voting to always result in consistent choices.

title: rent seeking
content: Attempts by individuals and firms to use government action to make themselves better off at the expense of others.

title: progressive tax
content: A tax for which people with lower income pay a lower percentage of their income in tax than do people with higher income.

title: regressive tax
content: A tax for which people with lower income pay a higher percentage of their income in tax than do people with higher income.

title: marginal tex rate
content: The fraction of each additional dollar of income that must be paid in taxes.

title: excess burden
content: A measure of the efficiency loss to the economy that results from a tax having reduced the quantity of a good produced; also known as the deadweight loss.

title: tax incidence
content: The actual dividion of the burden of a tax between buyers and sellers in a market.

title: poverty line
content: A level of annual income equal to three times the amount of money necessary to purchase the minimum quantity of food required for adequate nutrition.

title: poverty rate
content: The percentage of the population that is poor according to the federal government's definition.

title: Lorenz curve
content: A curve that shows the distribution of income by arraying incomes from lowest to highest on the horizontal axis and indicating the cumulative fraction of income earned by each fraction of households on the vertical axis.
